Apr 16

Toronto Raptors/Milwaukee Bucks Game 1 Analysis

16 Wins A Ring Writers offer 3 different perspectives on Game 1 results: Bucks 97- Raptors 83

Raptors Analysis by Tamberlyn Richardson

What Worked:

DeMar DeRozan had a quality first half driving and scoring through contact. In addition, Serge Ibaka was arguably the best Raptor on the court until Giannis Antetokounmpo undercut him on a 3-point attempt which resulted in the big man coming up gimpy. Hopefully it’s not a situation of the injury getting worse the day after.

Outside of these two and one decent quarter of Kyle Lowry plus the reserves there wasn’t much that went right.

P.J. Tucker Deal Caps Off A Brilliant Trade Deadline For Raptors
To follow up on landing Serge Ibaka, the Raptors have bolstered their wing play and defense even more with a trade for…16winsaring.com

Lessons Learned:

Other than the second quarter, this squad didn’t even come close to resembling the squad who finished the season 12–2.

Rumors of the team being stricken by a flu bug might be accurate, given the lethargic effort put forth. Toronto was slow on switches, were tentative taking shots and looked mired in quick sand running the court. Plus their transition defense was abysmal.

The players looked equally as confused as those witnessing these imposters wearing Raptors jerseys.

In the season series against Milwaukee the Raptors shot 47.22% from the field. A far cry from the 36% the Bucks held them to in Game 1. In fact, only two performances this season were worse and both occurred prior to the All-Star Break (one in early November).

As crazy as this loss seemed, it felt more like the Raptors gave the game away, then the Bucks won it.

Game 2 Adjustments:

It was expected there would be signs of rust for Kyle Lowry returning after an injury absence of 21 games. The bulldog’s rhythm was noticebly off, but the disconcerting issue was how much it effected his teammates. Poor floor spacing, ball watching, lack of ball and player movement all need to be cleaned up.

The Raptors failed to capitalize on a true advantage utilizing big man Jonas Valanciunas who the Bucks have no counter for. Moreover, five shot attempts isn’t going to cut it. He needs to either be involved more often or replaced by Jakob Poeltl who most consider a better defender.

Another frustration was how few in game adjustments Dwane Casey made to add energy or shift momentum. The Raptors are a deep talented squad — utilize them.

16 Wins A Ring All-Star: Kyle Lowry
Unlike the fans, the people here at 16 Wins A Ring got this one right and voted my man Kyle “Bubble Butt” Lowry into…16winsaring.com

Game 2 Prediction:

Toronto has now lost 10 of 11 Game 1 opportunities. For a team some (cough) picked to upset the Cavaliers, this squad needs to rediscover their identity and mojo immediately. Milwaukee has no expectations, so can play freely without pressure. That said, history tells us two things will happen.

  1. The natural comfort that comes from stealing a game on the opposing court will result in the Bucks intensity level decreasing, ever so slightly.
  2. DeMar DeRozan will return to the court Tuesday still sporting the scowl he left with today and the Raptors will win Game 2 convincingly. Hey, it’s the way we roll in the 6ix.

Bucks Analysis by Brian Sampson

What Worked:

Giannis Antetokounmpo went well for the Bucks as he was clearly the best player on the floor at all times. He was simply amazing and showed the NBA universe what Milwaukee Bucks fans have been seeing all season long.

Antetokounmpo did a little bit of everything in this game. On defense, he contested and bothered shots repeatedly and ripped down rebounds in traffic.

On offense, he excelled in transition but was able to score in the half court as well. He knocked down a couple of perimeter jumpers and was able to back down smaller defenders to get into a prime scoring position as well.

Giannis Antetokounmpo Has The Whole World In His Hands
When the gangly body of Giannis Antetokounmpo made its way across the stage to shake hands with Adam Silver when he was…16winsaring.com

Lessons Learned:

For most of the game the Bucks defense was absolutely terrific. They weren’t making anything easy for the Raptors.

However, in the second quarter the Bucks defense fell apart as they were outscored 16–29. During that quarter, the Raptors were able to get whatever they wanted inside the paint as the Bucks allowed way too many baskets around the rim.

A main reason the Raptors were able to have their way was due to the Bucks pairing Matthew Dellavedova and Malcolm Brogdon together in the backcourt.

Although Brogdon is a great perimeter defender, he is better suited to be matched up with point guards. He stands little chance when tasked with slowing down DeMar DeRozan who is both stronger and quicker than the rookie.

The Bucks must avoid this matchup as must as possible for the rest of the series. There is no reason that either Tony Snell or Khris Middleton shouldn’t be on the floor at all times with DeRozan.

Game 2 Adjustments:

Jason Kidd needs to tighten up his rotation. Kidd nearly emptied his bench in the first half, allowing 11 different players to see the floor.

The playoffs isn’t the time for Kidd to search for the hot hand. He needs to go with the 8 best guys on his team and stick with them for most of the game.

This rotation hurt the Bucks the most in the second quarter as they were outscored by 13 points.

Kidd quickly realized his mistake and tightened his rotation up in the second half leading to the Bucks comeback and ultimately, the victory.

The Rise of Malcolm Brogdon
Malcolm Brogdon is not your typical rookie.16winsaring.com

Game 2 Prediction:

The next game appears to be the classic trap game for the Milwaukee Bucks. They will be feeling themselves after playing some great basketball and will overlook the Raptors in Game 2.

Toronto, meanwhile, will be out for vengeance. DeRozan appeared to feel disrespected after Antetokounmpo swatted his fourth quarter shot attempt into the stands. Look for the Raptors to feed off their crowd and play with more passion and intensity in Game 2.

Toronto 101- Bucks 94

Toronto Raptors/Milwaukee Bucks Playoff Preview
16 Wins A Ring Writers offer 3 different perspectives on each first round series16winsaring.com

Independent Analysis by Keith P. Smith

Why Bucks Won and Raptors Lost:

The easy answer is Giannis Antetokounmpo. Antetokounmpo made several highlight plays on his way to 28 points on 13-of-18 shooting. But the Bucks real strengths were their offensive balance and their defense. Six players scored in double figures for Milwaukee, including 14 points and 15 rebounds from Greg Monroe off the bench.

On defense the Bucks held Toronto to 36% percent from the field and 5-of-23 from behind the arc. They focused their attention on DeMar DeRozan and Kyle Lowry, holding the two to a combined 9-of-32 from the floor. By staying attached to the bodies of the Raptors star guards, Milwaukee kept the normally efficient Toronto offense off kilter all night.

Game 2 Adjustments:

Bucks: Very little. The Bucks played terrific in almost all phases of the game. If we’re going to nitpick, they did foul a lot. DeRozan got 14 attempts and made 13 of them. If Toronto starts hitting shots, the extra points at the charity stripe will really start to add up.

Milwaukee also got beat on the glass by a 47–43 margin. That isn’t big, but the Raptors showed signs of being able to dominate the boards. The Bucks will have to keep their focus to compete in the rebounding action throughout the series.

Khris Middleton Can Help The Bucks Three-Point Shooting Problem
It was tough to predict how well the Milwaukee Bucks would do heading into this season. They had made some additions in…16winsaring.com

Raptors: The Raptors need to work the ball to Jonas Valanciunas more in the post. He got just five shot attempts and that is far too few. Valanciunas should be able to take advantage of Thon Maker inside and Toronto didn’t utilize him near enough.

Both Lowry and DeRozan should shoot better next time out, but working the ball inside to Valanciunas would go a long way towards helping the Raptors get going on offense.

Game 2 Prediction:

Down 1–0 and having lost home court advantage, Toronto is in familiar territory. And, like they have before, you can expect to see the Raptors come out with a supreme effort and even things up.

DeRozan and Lowry will play better and they’ll have some new wrinkles for guarding Antetokounmpo. And the home crowd will be even thirstier for a win, knowing that the season hangs in the balance if the Raptors were to drop two straight at home.
